node.text:
“If you’re drinking soya milk, that might have come from South America and caused deforestation, the destruction of species and the displacement of indigenous people.” 

“You're better off drinking milk from a local dairy farm that's been bottled there and delivered to your doorstep, where cows are wonderfully looked after and the family contribute to the local society and economy.” - Adam Henson. 

Today it’s time to take look at the facts. Is there’s any truth to the claims that plant milks are responsible for so much destruction?

And would it better for the planet to just have locally sourced dairy? And what about the animals, where do they come into this?

All sources are linked on the transcript: surgeactivism.org/plantmilks
.
.
.
.
.
#veganism #veganfortheanimals #environment #climatecrisis #plantbaseddiet #climatechange #environmental #ethical #localdairy #localdairyfarm #cheese #cheesenight #climatechangeisreal #cheeseandwine #localfarm #supportlocal #savetheplanet #savemotherearth #planetearth

node.text:
So happy to share with you all today our mid-year update from @thesurgesanctuary!

So much has happened since we filmed this update video (including the arrival of Matilda and her babies!) and I’m so proud of everything the team has been doing since our initial announcement. If you want to keep up-to-date with the incredible residents, be sure to follow @thesurgesanctuary.

Thank you all so much for your support as always, it means the world to us all. I hope you enjoy the update! #animalrescue

node.title: Surge Sanctuary: Where we’re at now 🌳

node.text:
Eating insects instead of conventionally farmed animals is being touted as the future of food, with headlines such as ‘If we want to save the planet, the future of food is insects’ hitting the news recently.

So today we take a look at the environmental and ethical arguments behind the proposed solution of eating insects.

In truth, the ethics of what we do to insects comes down to the insects’ capacity to suffer and experience subjectively, in essence, their sentience.

With the available knowledge that we have now on animal sentience, we might take the position that eating insects is morally preferable because they are less sentient than animals such as pigs, cows, chickens, fish and the animals we conventionally consume - but this argument misses the point.

The question isn’t ‘are they as sentient as other farmed animals’ but rather ‘are they sentient in a morally relevant way’? If we choose to ignore what is already being suggested about the consciousness of insects we may one day, in the same way that we have with other non-human animals, realise that their capacities exceed what we once thought.

All sources + transcript: surgeactivism.org/insectfarming

.
.
.
.
.

node.text:
“What about the smallpox microbes?” is definitely a new one.

The full video responding to Neil deGrasse Tyson’s podcast segment on species bias is up on my YouTube channel (link in bio).

Firstly and most obviously, it’s important to address the science behind ‘plants are alive too’.

A plant lacks a nervous system, pain receptors and a brain which means that anatomically they don’t have the ability to have conscious, subjective experiences, such as pain. If we also consider that the primary reason human and non-human animals feel pain is to alert us that we are in danger or are being hurt and that we need to escape the situation that we are in, a plant cannot move and thus any pain would be inescapable, making life torturous for any plant. 

Which begs the question, why would plants ever evolve such a horribly debilitating and destructive characteristic, as it goes against the fundamental purpose of evolution? 

Yes plants are alive and they conduct various activities at a cellular level. In fact, plants are capable of doing some truly amazing things, such as tilting to face the sunlight, but they do not conduct any activities at a conscious or cognitive level, in essence meaning that plants are not sentient.

It’s important that we don’t conflate intelligence with sentience. Viruses and bacteria also possess intelligence and do remarkable things, but they too are not sentient. 

I am doubtful that anyone truly believes that dropping a cauliflower into boiling water and boiling chickens alive (something that often happens in the chicken slaughtering process) is the same thing. 

But if you truly believe that plants deserve moral consideration in the same way that humans and non-human animals do - vastly more plants are used in the production of animal products than they are the production of plant-based products anyway.

On top of this, it’s important to note that animal farming is the number one driver of #rainforest deforestation and habitat destruction, meaning that millions of trees and plants have been and continue to be destroyed because of our consumption of animal products. 

#vegan #startalk #neildegrassetyson #whyvegan

node.text:
Today we go through the most frequently used arguments against vegans, including:

👉 It’s my personal choice to eat animal products.
👉 Animals taste good.
👉 Farmed animals can live a good life.
👉 Animals are killed humanely.
👉 Lions eat meat.
👉 We’ve eaten meat for thousands of years.
👉 Eating animal products is legal.
👉 We need to eat animal products for nutrients.
👉 Animals are bred to be killed.
👉 Plants are alive too.
👉 It’s cultural and traditional to eat animals.
👉 We’re more intelligent than animals.
👉 We’re top of the food chain.
👉 What about human rights?
👉 Veganism isn’t perfect.

📚 For more excuses and responses, head to https://earthlinged.org/ebook to download my entirely free e-book ‘30 Non-Vegan Excuses and How to Respond to Them’ or follow the link in my bio.

.
.
.
.
.

node.text:
BREAKING @surgeactivism INVESTIGATION:

Our new investigation into a Red Tractor approved pig farm in the UK has been just been released this morning in @the.independent. The farm supplies supermarkets Morrisons, Tesco, Sainsbury’s and later we discovered, Asda. All four of these major supermarkets however have now DROPPED Willerby World Piggeries as a supplier following the release. 

Whilst what our investigation shows is sickening, violence and cruelty are the norm on animal farms, with both the legal and illegal practices on farms causing extreme suffering.

Time and time again we are told that these investigations are bad apples and that they don’t represent the reality of animal farming. However, undercover investigations have exposed countless farms that are RSPCA Assured and Red Tractor certified - even farms owned by those in senior positions of the largest farming organisations in the UK, such as the NFU and Quality Meat Scotland.

At some point we have to recognise that these are not just bad apples but that the entire tree is rotten. The only way to end cruelty to animals is to be vegan.

Please share with someone who eats pig flesh products.

node.text:
And they say vegans are extreme.

Please listen. This is happening right now. It’s happening everywhere. Whilst the dairy industry perpetuates lies about their industry today on #WorldMilkDay, this is the reality. This is what is actually happening, and this is what we have to stop.

If you find this devastating to hear, imagine how the animals feel. Please choose vegan, because veganism is justice.

.
.
.
.
.

node.text:
In 2006, the United Nations stated:

“The livestock sector emerges as one of the top two or three most significant contributors to the most serious environmental problems, at every scale from local to global. The findings of this report suggest that it should be a major policy focus when dealing with problems of land degradation, climate change and air pollution, water shortage and water pollution, and loss of biodiversity.”

And then four years later, they warned that a global shift towards a vegan diet is vital to save the world from hunger, fuel poverty and the worst impacts of climate change.

So why exactly is animal farming so bad for the environment?

All sources + transcript: surgeactivism.org/aveganworld

#environment #climatecrisis #veganism #plantbaseddiet #climatechange #environmental #ethical #earthday2021 #earthday2020 #climateemergency #climateaction #climatechangeisreal #happyearthday #planetearthfirst #fastfashion #savetheplanet #savemotherearth #planetearth

node.text:
Again and again, the animal agriculture industries find themselves involved in shady and secretive actions. Whether it’s creating brand new diseases and causing pandemics, colluding and paying off government officials, or lying to the public, these industries have done it all. 

Today let’s take a look at how the animal agriculture industries poisoned drinking water in the US, and successfully got away with it. 

All sources + the full video ‘Shady practices of the meat industry uncovered’ at surgeactivism.org/biggest-agricultural-scandals 

#veganism #animalrights #steak #breakfast #lunch #dinner #vegetarian #dairyfarming #animalfarm #animalfarming #chickenrecipes #chickensalad #foodideas #foodlover #animalsofinstagram #animallovers

node.title: How animal agriculture poisoned drinking water (and got away with it) ☣️

node.text:
Farmers feeding dead cows back to cows? What could ever go wrong 😐

Bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE), commonly known as mad cow disease, and the human variant, Variant Creutzfeldt–Jakob disease (vCJD) sound like something out of a horror movie.

However this disease isn’t something out of a work of fiction, it’s a direct creation of the animal farming industries. 

Full video ‘Shady secrets of the meat industry uncovered’ on my YouTube channel.

All sources at surgeactivism.org/biggest-agricultural-scandals 

#veganism #animalrights #steak #breakfast #lunch #dinner #vegetarian #dairyfarming #animalfarm #animalfarming #cowsofinstagram #cowsmakemehappy #foodideas #foodlover #animalsofinstagram #animallovers

node.title: How animal farmers created a new neurological disease

node.text:
Did you know that this is how bacon ends up on our plate?

The concentration of carbon dioxide is normally 80% or higher in slaughterhouse gas chambers, which is recognised as being highly toxic for pigs, with concentrations above 20% having been shown to create a toxic reaction.

The carbon dioxide replaces the oxygen in the pigs, causing them to hyperventilate and thrash about in a state of panic as they lose consciousness. The CO2 also forms an acid when it comes into contact with wet surfaces, such as the eyes, lungs and throats of the pigs, causing them pain and distress alongside the suffocation.

This process can take longer than 60 seconds. Disturbingly, in 2003, the UK government’s animal welfare advisory body recommended that gas chambers should banned, but they have instead become more prevalent. Today, this is how 86% of the pigs in the UK are slaughtered.

Can we really justify this atrocity, just so that we can eat bacon, ham and sausages? Especially when there are vegan alternatives to all of these products.

👉 To help end this needless violence, head to the link in my bio to watch ‘how to go vegan in 5 simple steps’ 🌱

#bacon #baconsandwich #baconbaconbacon #baconislove #baconislife #veganism #vegansofig 

📚 Sources:

Behavioral Response of Weaned Pigs during Gas Euthanasia with CO2, CO2 with Butorphanol, or Nitrous Oxide. 

Time to Loss of Consciousness and Its Relation to Behavior in Slaughter Pigs during Stunning with 80 or 95% Carbon Dioxide.

Results of the 2018 FSA Survey into Slaughter Methods in England and Wales, DEFRA, February 2019.

node.text:
“If you’re drinking soya milk, that might have come from South America and caused deforestation, the destruction of species and the displacement of indigenous people.” 

“You're better off drinking milk from a local dairy farm that's been bottled there and delivered to your doorstep, where cows are wonderfully looked after and the family contribute to the local society and economy.” - Adam Henson. 

Today it’s time to take look at the facts. Is there’s any truth to the claims that plant milks are responsible for so much destruction?

And would it better for the planet to just have locally sourced dairy? And what about the animals, where do they come into this?

All sources are linked on the transcript: surgeactivism.org/plantmilks
.
.
.
.
.
#veganism #veganfortheanimals #environment #climatecrisis #plantbaseddiet #climatechange #environmental #ethical #localdairy #localdairyfarm #cheese #cheesenight #climatechangeisreal #cheeseandwine #localfarm #supportlocal #savetheplanet #savemotherearth #planetearth

node.text:
So happy to share with you all today our mid-year update from @thesurgesanctuary!

So much has happened since we filmed this update video (including the arrival of Matilda and her babies!) and I’m so proud of everything the team has been doing since our initial announcement. If you want to keep up-to-date with the incredible residents, be sure to follow @thesurgesanctuary.

Thank you all so much for your support as always, it means the world to us all. I hope you enjoy the update! #animalrescue

node.text:
In recent years we have become used to hearing about catastrophic climate events, with wildfires across Australia and South America, as well as other places, creating headlines around the world.
 
However, 2021 has felt different. The past few months have brought us an unrelenting barrage of climate disasters. #Wildfires, deadly #heatwaves, droughts and #floods, the scale of destruction and the unpredictability of events surely must be enough for us to realise the urgency of the situation we are in. If we fail to act now, when we face the consequences in the future we won’t be able to blame our inaction on not being given enough warnings.

As individuals, we have more power to influence positive change than we often realise. A University of Oxford report stated that even if the use of fossil fuels ended immediately, the emissions produced by the agricultural sector alone would make it impossible to limit warming to 1.5 degrees celsius and would even make it difficult to not hit 2 degrees. Consequently, the food that we eat plays a huge role in shaping what our future will look like.

Shifting to a plant-based diet could reduce agricultural emissions by as much as 73% in high-income nations and would also reduce the amount of agricultural land that we need by 75% (an area of land equivalent in size to China, Australia, the US + the entire European Union combined), making it the most impactful way for us to restore and reforest the natural world. In essence, it removes one of the most destructive industries and replaces it with one of our best solutions to the climate crisis.

Not to mention, a #plantbased diet removes the number one cause of rainforest deforestation, habitat loss and species extinction, and would reduce soil acidification, water pollution and eutrophication, freshwater use and other environmental problems. As the lead researcher of the most comprehensive analysis on the impact of farming and the environment stated, “A plant-based diet is probably the single biggest way to reduce your impact on planet Earth.” 

Credits: 

Photography: @mishka_bochkaryov

—

@earthfocus
Rhein-Erft-Kreis/Reuters

Sources all linked:
🌐 surgeactivism.org/aveganworld

node.text:
I don’t know about you, but it sometimes feels like I’m stuck in Groundhog Day. No matter how often we talk about the issue of soy farming in the Amazon, whenever it gets brought up, vegans still get told that it’s their fault. 

The recent news about the Amazon rainforest now emitting more CO2 than it absorbs has been no different. 

Firstly, the biggest problem in the Amazon #rainforest is the cattle ranching industry. In fact, it’s estimated that 80% of all Brazilian Amazon rainforest loss has been for cattle farming.

The next major contributor is the soy industry, but not because of vegans consuming soy products. Globally, somewhere in the region of 75 to 80% of all the soy that is produced is used as animal feed. When looking specifically at South America, 90% of soymeal produced in Brazil is used as animal feed, with it is also being estimated that over 96% of all the soy produced in South America is used as animal feed or cooking oil. This is not about soya milk, #tofu, tempeh or plant-based alternatives.

Soy is used as feed for farmed animals all over the world, including in the UK. In fact, the UK imports somewhere around 3.2 million tons of soy every single year, over 75% of which comes from South America. 

Of this imported soy, at least 90% of it is used as feed for farmed animals, with it estimated that very little, if any, of the soy imported from South America is used directly for human food. It’s also easy to go on to the websites of plant-based brands to find out where they source their soy from. Brands such as Plenish and Provamel, for example, source the soy they use for their plant milks from Europe.

So if you want to save the Amazon rainforest the best place to start is by changing what’s on your plate. 

Sources in comments.

node.text:
Eating insects instead of conventionally farmed animals is being touted as the future of food, with headlines such as ‘If we want to save the planet, the future of food is insects’ hitting the news recently.

So today we take a look at the environmental and ethical arguments behind the proposed solution of eating insects.

In truth, the ethics of what we do to insects comes down to the insects’ capacity to suffer and experience subjectively, in essence, their sentience.

With the available knowledge that we have now on animal sentience, we might take the position that eating insects is morally preferable because they are less sentient than animals such as pigs, cows, chickens, fish and the animals we conventionally consume - but this argument misses the point.

The question isn’t ‘are they as sentient as other farmed animals’ but rather ‘are they sentient in a morally relevant way’? If we choose to ignore what is already being suggested about the consciousness of insects we may one day, in the same way that we have with other non-human animals, realise that their capacities exceed what we once thought.

All sources + transcript: surgeactivism.org/insectfarming

.
.
.
.
.

node.text:
Read the caption 👇 

The pig industry claims that farrowing crates are used to stop the mother pigs from crushing their piglets.

However, research has shown that there is no difference in piglet mortality between those who are kept in the crates and those who are not.

The truth is, gestation crates and farrowing crates allow #farmers to house more #pigs in less space and are the most cost efficient way of farming the highest number of pigs possible. 

We incarcerate these animals in cages that they can’t even turn around in, just so we can then force them into gas chambers, kill them and then eat their bodies, which we euphemistically refer to as bacon (which is also a class 1 carcinogen). Then, to top it all off, we call this process humane and high welfare.

It doesn’t have to be this way, we can end violence against animals every time we choose vegan. 

🌐 Head to the link in my bio to watch ‘how to go vegan in 5 simple steps’ 🌱

.
.
.
.
.

node.text:
It’s important to note that anti-speciesists recognise that humans and non-humans are vastly different in many ways, including our physical form, intelligence and sociability, among others. However, it is not the differences that are relevant when deciding whether non-humans matter morally, but instead the similarities. Fundamentally, sentience, meaning the capacity to feel and experience subjectively.

If it is sentience that makes human animals worthy of moral consideration, then in the same way it is sentience that makes non-human animals worthy of moral consideration as well. 

And even if we were to believe that morally there is a distinction between a human and a non-human, that distinction is surely not so significant that it justifies the unnecessary torture and slaughter of hundreds of billions of non-human animals every single year.

After all, any amount of moral worth should prohibit the act of slaughter, especially as the mere objective reality that animals can suffer and have subjective experiences immediately withdraws any notion of acceptability when it comes to exploiting them.

.
.
.
.
.

Photo shared by Earthling Ed on July 15, 2021 tagging @weanimals. May be an image of one or more people and text that says '....... "Speciesism is a prejudice or attitude of bias in favour of the interests of members of one's own species and against those of members of other species." -PETER SINGER PHOTO WE ANIMALS EARTHLING ED'.

Photo shared by Earthling Ed on July 15, 2021 tagging @weanimals. May be an image of food and text that says '.·.... In other words, speciesism is a prejudice that says it's okay to favour a human's desire to eat a bacon sandwich over a pig's desire to not be killed in a gas chamber, or to treat a dog like a family member but a pig like a disposable object. PHOTO WE ANIMALS EARTHLING ED'.

Photo shared by Earthling Ed on July 15, 2021 tagging @weanimals. May be an image of text that says '.··.. Speciesism has allowed US to create world where trillions of animals are killed every single year, with tens of billions of them living an abject and horrific life. Their bodies are mutilated, their reproductive systems are abused and their babies are stolen. Their individuality and desire to avoid suffering is ignored, and their lives are ultimately taken from them by force. PHOTO: WE ANIMALS EARTHLING ED'.

Photo shared by Earthling Ed on July 15, 2021 tagging @weanimals. May be an image of text that says '....·· Speciesism carries the idea of human superiority to the extreme of believing that trivial and needless human desires are morally permissible such as skinning animals for a fur or leather jacket, forcing pigs into gas chambers for a bacon sandwich or separating newborn calves from their mothers so that we can drink their mother's milk. PHOTO: WE ANIMALS EARTHLING ED'.

Photo by Earthling Ed on July 15, 2021. May be an image of text that says '…····· However, the position of anti-speciesists is that it is not morally justifiable to discriminate against an animal simply because of their body, in the same way that it is not morally justified to discriminate against a human simply because of the body they were born into. EARTHLING ED'.

Photo by Earthling Ed on July 15, 2021. May be an image of text that says '...... Ultimately, speciesism is so ingrained and normalised within society that we don't even consider it a problem. People will often laugh at others who raise these issues, but of course it's much easier to mock the idea of animals having basic rights, than it is to look at a piece of steak on a dinner plate and attempt to justify why animals have such little worth that they should have their throats cut simply because we enjoy eating a piece of their body. EARTHLING ED'.

node.text:
“What about the smallpox microbes?” is definitely a new one.

The full video responding to Neil deGrasse Tyson’s podcast segment on species bias is up on my YouTube channel (link in bio).

Firstly and most obviously, it’s important to address the science behind ‘plants are alive too’.

A plant lacks a nervous system, pain receptors and a brain which means that anatomically they don’t have the ability to have conscious, subjective experiences, such as pain. If we also consider that the primary reason human and non-human animals feel pain is to alert us that we are in danger or are being hurt and that we need to escape the situation that we are in, a plant cannot move and thus any pain would be inescapable, making life torturous for any plant. 

Which begs the question, why would plants ever evolve such a horribly debilitating and destructive characteristic, as it goes against the fundamental purpose of evolution? 

Yes plants are alive and they conduct various activities at a cellular level. In fact, plants are capable of doing some truly amazing things, such as tilting to face the sunlight, but they do not conduct any activities at a conscious or cognitive level, in essence meaning that plants are not sentient.

It’s important that we don’t conflate intelligence with sentience. Viruses and bacteria also possess intelligence and do remarkable things, but they too are not sentient. 

I am doubtful that anyone truly believes that dropping a cauliflower into boiling water and boiling chickens alive (something that often happens in the chicken slaughtering process) is the same thing. 

But if you truly believe that plants deserve moral consideration in the same way that humans and non-human animals do - vastly more plants are used in the production of animal products than they are the production of plant-based products anyway.

On top of this, it’s important to note that animal farming is the number one driver of #rainforest deforestation and habitat destruction, meaning that millions of trees and plants have been and continue to be destroyed because of our consumption of animal products. 

#vegan #startalk #neildegrassetyson #whyvegan

node.text:
Today we go through the most frequently used arguments against vegans, including:

👉 It’s my personal choice to eat animal products.
👉 Animals taste good.
👉 Farmed animals can live a good life.
👉 Animals are killed humanely.
👉 Lions eat meat.
👉 We’ve eaten meat for thousands of years.
👉 Eating animal products is legal.
👉 We need to eat animal products for nutrients.
👉 Animals are bred to be killed.
👉 Plants are alive too.
👉 It’s cultural and traditional to eat animals.
👉 We’re more intelligent than animals.
👉 We’re top of the food chain.
👉 What about human rights?
👉 Veganism isn’t perfect.

📚 For more excuses and responses, head to https://earthlinged.org/ebook to download my entirely free e-book ‘30 Non-Vegan Excuses and How to Respond to Them’ or follow the link in my bio.

.
.
.
.
.

node.text:
The Yulin Dog Meat Festival is underway, and whilst it is a morally repugnant event that shouldn’t take place, it is not only the consumption of dogs that is abhorrent.

After all, morally, what is the difference between eating a dog or a cow, pig, #chicken, lamb, tuna, or any animal that we consume in the cultures where we live? All of these animals are sentient and suffer because of what we do to them, so why is it only morally wrong to kill the animals that we don’t personally want to eat? 

In reality the reason we eat the animals we do is because of the cultures that we are raised in. But should culture dictate morality? When we consider that there are many cultural practices that cause immense suffering to humans, as well as to non-human animals, it becomes very obvious that it shouldn’t. 

So with this in mind, how can we morally justify gassing a pig to death for bacon, or macerating a male chick just because we want to eat eggs?
